greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: a(n) is least natural number b such that b^(2^n) + (b-1)^(2^n) is prime.
comment: When a(n) is 2, the corresponding prime is a Fermat prime, otherwise it is a so-called extended generalized Fermat prime sometimes denoted xGF(n, b, b-1) or similar.
link: Henri Lifchitz & Renaud Lifchitz, PRP Top Records, search for x^16384+y^16384, related to a(14).
example: For n = 5, 2^5 = 32 is the exponent.  The numbers 1^32 + 0^32, 2^32 + 1^32, ..., 8^32 + 7^32 are not prime, but 9^32 + 8^32 is prime, so a(5) = 9. - _Michael B. Porter_, Mar 28 2018
results.author: _Jeppe Stig Nielsen_, Jan 07 2015
ext: a(14) found by Henri Lifchitz in 2007, from _Jeppe Stig Nielsen_, Apr 17 2018
